name: Metformin (Glucophage) – for Antipsychotic-Induced Weight Gain
summary: A biguanide antihyperglycemic agent used off-label to mitigate weight gain and metabolic disturbances from antipsychotic medications.
description: Metformin is an oral biguanide used primarily for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Off-label, it is prescribed to reduce weight gain, insulin resistance, and other metabolic effects associated with antipsychotic treatment—particularly second-generation antipsychotics like olanzapine and clozapine. Its mechanism involves decreasing hepatic glucose production, improving peripheral insulin sensitivity, and modestly reducing appetite. Clinical studies support its role in attenuating weight gain and improving metabolic parameters in psychiatric populations.

contraindications: Acute metabolic acidosis, including diabetic ketoacidosis

items: Prevention of metabolic syndrome in patients on antipsychotics

sections.text: Reduces hepatic glucose production, increases peripheral glucose uptake, and may decrease appetite via central and gastrointestinal effects.

adult.titrate: Increase by 500 mg weekly as tolerated

sections.geriatric: Initiate at lower dose and monitor renal function closely
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use caution; not recommended in significant impairment
sections.renal_impairment: Contraindicated if eGFR < 30; reduce dose if eGFR 30–45

sections.text: Weight and metabolic improvements may be observed within 8–12 weeks; maximum effect in several months.

other: Risk of lactic acidosis increases with renal dysfunction, excessive alcohol intake, and acute illness
Withhold temporarily for procedures involving contrast dye or conditions predisposing to hypoxia

items.action: Hold metformin before and after procedure if eGFR < 60

items: Renal function (baseline and at least annually)
Vitamin B12 levels with long-term use

sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk in low amounts; generally safe
sections.pediatrics: Limited data for antipsychotic weight gain; some use in adolescents

sections.text: No pharmacologic withdrawal risk; can stop abruptly if necessary, but taper may reduce GI intolerance when restarting.

items: Best used early in antipsychotic treatment to prevent excessive weight gain
Combines well with lifestyle interventions for optimal effect
Extended-release formulations may reduce GI side effects
